### Amazon S3 Security
- Use access management features like IAM, ACLs, bucket policies, and Query String Authentication. SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/s3/security/
- Enable S3 Block Public Access to prevent public access. SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/s3/security/
- Perform Trusted Advisor checks for S3 bucket security. SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/s3/security/
- Encrypt data using server-side encryption options (SSE-S3, SSE-KMS, SSE-C). SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/s3/security/

### Top 10 Security Best Practices for Securing Data in Amazon S3
- Protect data from accidental deletion using S3 Versioning and Object Lock. SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/top-10-security-best-practices-for-securing-data-in-amazon-s3/
- Verify all access with bucket policies. SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/top-10-security-best-practices-for-securing-data-in-amazon-s3/
- Use organization-wide preventative controls with AWS Organizations. SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/top-10-security-best-practices-for-securing-data-in-amazon-s3/
- Leverage Amazon S3 Block Public Access. SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/top-10-security-best-practices-for-securing-data-in-amazon-s3/
- Encrypt data at rest and in transit. SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/top-10-security-best-practices-for-securing-data-in-amazon-s3/
- Enable MFA Delete and implement least privilege access. SOURCE: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/top-10-security-best-practices-for-securing-data-in-amazon-s3/

### Amazon S3 Security Best Practices
- Use server-side encryption to protect data at rest. SOURCE: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/security-best-practices.html
- Implement least privilege access control and use AWS Config for compliance. SOURCE: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/security-best-practices.html

### Security Controls for Amazon S3
- Enable MFA Delete for S3 buckets. SOURCE: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/UsingMFADelete.html
- Encrypt data at rest conforming to CIS standards. SOURCE: https://d1.awsstatic.com/whitepapers/compliance/AWS_CIS_Foundations_Benchmark.pdf
- Enable server access logging as per NIST Cybersecurity Framework. SOURCE: https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/CSWP/NIST.CSWP.04162018.pdf
- Use S3 Block Public Access as per AWS Security Best Practices. SOURCE: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/access-control-block-public-access.html
- Regularly review S3 bucket permissions as recommended by CIS. SOURCE: https://d1.awsstatic.com/whitepapers/compliance/AWS_CIS_Foundations_Benchmark.pdf
- Ensure data integrity with STIGs recommendations for data protection. SOURCE: https://public.cyber.mil/stigs/
- Implement bucket policies to restrict IP addresses based on NIST guidelines. SOURCE: https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/CSWP/NIST.CSWP.04162018.pdf
- Monitor S3 bucket settings with AWS Config. SOURCE: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/WhatIsConfig.html

**Template**

Implement the principle of least privilege for IAM permissions (AWS Security Best Practices): Ensure IAM policies for S3 are restricted to necessary operations. SOURCE: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/best-practices.html

1. **Enable MFA Delete for S3 Buckets (AWS Security Best Practices)**: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) adds an additional layer of security when deleting objects from S3 buckets. Source: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/UsingMFADelete.html

2. **Encrypt S3 Data at Rest (CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark)**: Ensure that all S3 buckets have server-side encryption enabled to protect data at rest. Source: https://d1.awsstatic.com/whitepapers/compliance/AWS_CIS_Foundations_Benchmark.pdf

3. **Enable S3 Bucket Logging (NIST Cybersecurity Framework)**: Enable server access logging for S3 buckets to maintain records of access requests. This aligns with the NIST framework’s emphasis on continuous monitoring and logging. Source: https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/CSWP/NIST.CSWP.04162018.pdf

4. **Use S3 Block Public Access (AWS Security Best Practices)**: Block public access settings should be enabled for all S3 buckets to prevent accidental data exposure or leaks. Source: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/access-control-block-public-access.html

5. **Regularly Review S3 Bucket Permissions (CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark)**: Periodically audit S3 bucket ACLs and policy permissions to ensure that they grant access only as intended, adhering to the principle of least privilege. Source: https://d1.awsstatic.com/whitepapers/compliance/AWS_CIS_Foundations_Benchmark.pdf

6. **Enable S3 Data Integrity Authentication (STIGs)**: Use mechanisms like S3 Versioning and MFA Delete to prevent unauthorized data alteration or deletion, in line with Security Technical Implementation Guides (STIGs) practices. Though STIGs do not specifically mention Amazon S3, the principle of ensuring data integrity is relevant. Source: https://public.cyber.mil/stigs/

7. **Implement Bucket Policies to Restrict IP Addresses (NIST Cybersecurity Framework)**: Use S3 bucket policies to restrict access to buckets from allowed IP ranges only, supporting the principle of limiting access to known entities. Source: https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/CSWP/NIST.CSWP.04162018.pdf

8. **Utilize AWS Config to Monitor and Record S3 Bucket Settings (AWS Security Best Practices)**: Use AWS Config to continuously monitor the configuration of your S3 buckets and record changes to ensure compliance with your organization’s security policies. Source: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/WhatIsConfig.html 

Please note that the URLs provided lead to general resources where you can find further information related to each recommendation. The specific guidelines or practices mentioned may be part of larger documents or frameworks, and the provided links directly access the respective organization’s or framework's general page or a related document.

The webpage titled "Amazon S3 Security Best Practices" from the AWS Documentation provides several essential security recommendations for Amazon S3:

1. **Protect Data at Rest Using Server-Side Encryption**: It emphasizes the need for encrypting objects before saving them on disks in Amazon S3 data centers. Amazon S3 offers multiple server-side encryption options:
   - Server-side encryption with Amazon S3-managed keys (SSE-S3)
   - Server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (SSE-KMS)
   - Server-side encryption with customer-provided keys (SSE-C)

2. **Implement Least Privilege Access Control**:
   - Utilize Amazon S3 actions and Permissions Boundaries for IAM Entities to ensure that only the necessary permissions are granted.
   - Use Bucket policies and user policies for fine-grained access control.
   - Understand and use Access Control List (ACL) overview for legacy access control needs.
   - Employ Service Control Policies (SCPs) for organization-wide policy enforcement.

3. **Use AWS Config for Compliance and Security Analysis**:
   - Leverage AWS Config to review changes in configurations and relationships between AWS resources.
   - Investigate detailed resource configuration histories to understand access and changes over time.
   - Determine overall compliance against configurations specified by your guidelines, aiding in simplification of compliance auditing, security analysis, change management, and operational troubleshooting.

These recommendations are designed to help users enhance the security posture of their Amazon S3 environments by focusing on data encryption, least privilege access control, and utilizing AWS Config for continuous monitoring and compliance checks.

Source: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/security-best-practices.html

The webpage titled "Top 10 Security Best Practices for Securing Data in Amazon S3" outlines the following security recommendations for Amazon S3:

1. **Protect Data from Accidental Deletion with S3 Versioning and Object Lock**: It's recommended to enable S3 Versioning to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your buckets. Additionally, S3 Object Lock can prevent objects from being deleted during a fixed amount of time or indefinitely.

2. **Verify All Access with Bucket Policies**: Ensure that the access granted in the Amazon S3 bucket policy is restricted to specific AWS principals, federated users, service principals, IP addresses, or VPCs that you specify. This helps in ensuring that access is not overly permissive.

3. **Utilize Organization-Wide Preventative Controls with AWS Organizations**: Use service control policies (SCPs) for enforcing permission guardrails across your AWS accounts. This is particularly important for securing your data in S3 organization-wide.

4. **Use AWS Config Rules to Evaluate Configuration Compliance**: Implement AWS Config rules to continuously monitor and record your S3 buckets for compliance with your organization's policies. This helps in identifying non-compliant configurations and taking corrective action.

5. **Leverage Amazon S3 Block Public Access**: Amazon S3 Block Public Access provides controls across an entire AWS Account or at the individual bucket level to ensure that objects never have public access, irrespective of how the access is configured.

6. **Classify Your Data**: Understand and classify your data stored in S3 buckets. Use tools like Amazon Macie, which automatically discovers, classifies, and protects sensitive data in AWS.

7. **Encrypt Data at Rest**: Encrypt your S3 data at rest using server-side encryption options such as Amazon S3-managed keys (SSE-S3), AWS Key Management Service (KMS)-managed keys (SSE-KMS), or customer-provided keys (SSE-C).

8. **Encrypt Data in Transit**: Ensure data is encrypted in transit to S3 using SSL/TLS.

9. **Enable MFA (Multi-Factor Authentication) Delete**: Enabling MFA Delete adds an additional layer of security by requiring MFA to delete an object version.

10. **Implement Least Privilege Access**: Grant least privilege access necessary by using IAM roles and policies, bucket policies, and Access Control Lists (ACLs).

These best practices aim to help AWS customers ensure their S3 data is secure, properly managed, and protected against unauthorized access or accidental deletion.

Source: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/top-10-security-best-practices-for-securing-data-in-amazon-s3/

The webpage titled "Amazon S3 Security" contains key security recommendations related to Amazon S3, which include:

1. **Access Management Features**: To manage access to Amazon S3 resources, it's recommended to use a combination of AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies, Access Control Lists (ACLs), bucket policies, and Query String Authentication. These tools allow for granular access control.

2. **Block Public Access**: Amazon S3 offers a feature to block all public access to your S3 buckets. This is crucial for preventing unintentional public exposure of sensitive data.

3. **Trusted Advisor Checks for Amazon S3**: Utilize AWS Trusted Advisor to perform security checks on your S3 buckets. These checks include the logging configuration of Amazon S3 buckets, ensuring that there are no open access permissions on S3 buckets, and fault tolerance checks such as ensuring that buckets have versioning enabled.

4. **Use Server-Side Encryption**: To protect data at rest, Amazon S3 supports server-side encryption. There are three server-side encryption options available: 
    - Server-side encryption with Amazon S3 managed keys (SSE-S3)
    - Server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (SSE-KMS)
    - Server-side encryption with customer-provided keys (SSE-C)

5. **Amazon S3 Security and Data Protection eBook**: For more comprehensive guidance on access management, auditing and monitoring, and data protection, the page suggests reading the Amazon S3 Security and Data Protection eBook.

These security recommendations emphasize the importance of access control, encryption, and configuration monitoring to safeguard data stored in Amazon S3.

Source: https://aws.amazon.com/s3/security/

The webpage titled "Strengthen the Security of Sensitive Data Stored in Amazon S3 by Using Additional AWS Services" contains the following security recommendations for Amazon S3:

1. **Utilizing S3 Object Lambda with Amazon Comprehend**: This recommendation involves creating an S3 Object Lambda Access Point from the S3 Management Console and selecting or invoking an AWS-built Lambda function. The purpose is to process objects and data from S3 dynamically, enhancing security by automatically scanning resources in your defined zone of trust and identifying sensitive information.

2. **Creating IAM Access Analyzer with Zone of Trust**: Create an analyzer with the current account or organization as the zone of trust. IAM Access Analyzer scans the resources in your zone of trust and returns findings from your Amazon S3 storage environment, helping to identify and remediate potential security issues.

3. **Monitoring and Remediating Configuration Changes with AWS Config**: This involves using AWS Config for configuration management to prevent unauthorized access to S3 buckets. AWS Config helps in reviewing changes in configurations and investigating detailed resource-configuration histories which is essential for maintaining the security of Amazon S3 content.

The recommendations focus on detecting sensitive data, monitoring configuration changes, and utilizing Lambda functions for dynamic data processing to strengthen the security of sensitive data stored in Amazon S3.

Source: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/strengthen-the-security-of-sensitive-data-stored-in-amazon-s3-by-using-additional-aws-services/
